The public officer shall cause to be posted on the main entrance of the building, dwelling, or structure a placard with the following words: "This building is unfit for human habitation or commercial, industrial, or business use and does not comply with the applicable codes or has been ordered secured to prevent its use in connection with drug crimes or constitutes an endangerment to the public health or safety as a result of unsanitary or unsafe conditions. The use or occupation of this building is prohibited and unlawful." (f) If the public officer has the structure demolished, reasonable effort shall be made to salvage reusable materials for credit against the cost of demolition. The proceeds of any moneys received from the sale of salvaged materials shall be used or applied against the cost of the demolition and removal of the structure, and proper records shall be kept showing the application of sales proceeds. Any such sale of salvaged materials may be made without the necessity of public advertisement and bid. The public officer and the city are relieved of any and all liability resulting from or occasioned by the sale of any such salvaged materials, including, without limitation, defects in such salvaged materials. (g) The amount of the cost of demolition, including all court costs, appraisal fees, administrative costs incurred by the tax commissioner, and all other costs necessarily associated with the abatement action, including restoration to grade of the real property after demolition, shall be a lien against the real property upon which such cost was incurred. (h) With respect to the lien provided for in this article: (1) The lien shall attach to the real property upon the filing of a certified copy of the order requiring repair, closure or demolition in the office of the clerk of superior court in the county and shall relate back to the date of the filing of the lis pendens notice required under O.C.G.A. § 41-2-12(g). The clerk of superior court shall record and index such certified copy of the order in the deed records of the county and enter the lien on the general execution docket. The lien shall be superior to all other liens on the property, except liens for taxes to which the lien shall be inferior, and shall continue in force until paid. After filing a certified copy of the order with the clerk of superior court, the public officer shall forward a copy of the order and a final statement of costs to the county tax commissioner. It shall be the duty of the county tax commissioner to collect the amount of the lien in conjunction with the collection of ad valorem taxes on the property and to collect the amount of the lien as if it were a real property ad valorem tax, using all methods available for the collection of real property ad valorem tax, including specifically O.C.G.A. § 48-4-1; provided, however that the limitation of O.C.G.A. § 48-4-78 which requires 12 months of delinquency before commencing a tax foreclosure shall not apply. The tax commissioner shall remit the amount collected to the governing authority of the city. Thirty days after imposition of the lien, the unpaid lien amount shall bear interest and penalties in the same amount as applicable to interest and penalties on unpaid real property ad valorem taxes; (2) The tax commissioner shall collect and retain an amount equal to the cost of administering a lien authorized by O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7 et seq., unless such costs are waived by resolution of the county. Any such amount collected and retained for administration shall be deposited in the general fund of the county to pay the cost of administering the lien; and (3) The city may waive and release any such lien imposed on property upon the owner of such property entering into a contract with the city agreeing to a timetable for rehabilitation of the real property or the dwelling, building, or structure on the property and demonstrating the financial means to accomplish such rehabilitation. (3) (i) Where the abatement action does not commence in the superior court, review of a court order requiring the repair, alteration, improvement, or demolition of a dwelling, building, or structure shall be by direct appeal to the superior court under O.C.G.A. § 5-3-29. (j) The public officers designated herein may issue citations for violations of state minimum standard codes, optional building, fire, life safety, and other codes adopted by ordinance, and conditions creating a public health hazard or general nuisance, and may seek to enforce such citation in court of competent jurisdiction prior to issuing a complaint in rem as provided in this article. (k) Nothing in this article shall be construed to impair or limit in any way the power of the city to define and declare nuisances and to cause their removal or abatement by summary proceedings or otherwise. Nothing in this article shall be construed to abrogate or impair the powers of the courts or of any department of the city to enforce any provisions of any local enabling act, charter, or ordinance or regulation nor to prevent or punish violations thereof; and the powers conferred by this article shall be in addition to and supplemental to the powers conferred by any other law or ordinance, legislation, or regulation. Sec. 38-26. - Determinations by public officer under existing ordinances. (a) The public officer may determine, under existing ordinances, that a dwelling, building, or structure is unfit for human habitation or is unfit for its current commercial, industrial, or business use if he finds that conditions exist in such building, dwelling, or structure which are dangerous or injurious to the health, safety, or morals of the occupants of such dwelling, building, or structure; of the occupants of neighborhood dwellings, buildings, or structures; or of other residents of the city. Such conditions include the following (without limiting the generality of the foregoing): (1) Defects therein increasing the hazards of fire, accidents or other calamities; (2) Lack of adequate ventilation, light, or sanitary facilities; (3) Dilapidation; (4) Disrepair; (5) Structural defects; (6) Uncleanliness; and (7) Other additional standards which may from time to time be adopted and referenced herein by ordinance amendment. (b) The public officer may determine, under existing ordinances, that a dwelling, building, or structure is vacant, dilapidated, and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes based upon personal observation or report of a law enforcement agency and evidence of drug crimes being committed. Sec. 38-27. - Powers of public officers. In addition to any other powers granted elsewhere under this article, the public officers designated in this article shall have the following powers: (1) To investigate the dwelling conditions in the city in order to determine which dwellings, buildings, or structures therein are unfit for human habitation or are unfit for current commercial, industrial, or business use or are vacant, dilapidated, and being used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; (2) To administer oaths and affirmations, to examine witnesses, and to receive evidence; (3) To enter upon premises for the purpose of making examinations; provided, however, that such entries shall be made in such manner as to cause the least possible inconvenience to the persons in possession; (4) To appoint and fix the duties of such officers, agents, and employees as he deems necessary to carry out the purposes of this article; (5) To delegate any of his functions and powers under this article to such officers and agents as he may designate; and (6) To take any other lawful actions which are necessary or convenient to carry out and effectuate the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 41-2-7—41-2-17 or this article. Sec. 38-28. - Service of complaints. (a) Complaints issued by a public officer pursuant to this article shall be served in the following manner. In all cases, a copy of the complaint and summons shall be conspicuously posted on the subject dwelling, building, or structure within three business days of filing of the complaint and at least ten days prior to the date of the hearing. A copy of the complaint and summons shall be served in one of the following ways: (1) Personal service upon each owner and party in interest if such parties are residents of the county. Service shall be perfected at least ten days prior to the date of the hearing. Service may be made by the public officer designated by ordinance to abate nuisances or by any law enforcement officer of the city; and a return of service, filed with the clerk of the appropriate court, shall be deemed sufficient proof that service was perfected; (2) Pursuant to the provisions of Article 5, Chapter 4 of Title 48 of the O.C.G.A (O.C.G.A. § 48-4-75 et seq.); or (3) Statutory overnight delivery. (b) If any owner or party in interest is a resident of this state but resides outside of the county, service shall be perfected by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery, return receipt requested, to the most recent address shown in the county tax filings and mailed at least 14 days prior to the date of the hearing. (c) Nonresidents of this state, whose mailing address is known, shall be served by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery, return receipt requested, mailed at least 14 days prior to the date of the hearing. For nonresidents whose mailing address is unknown, a notice stating the date, time, and place of the hearing shall be published in the newspaper in which the county sheriff's advertisements appear in such county once a week for two consecutive weeks prior to the hearing. (d) In the event either the owner or any party in interest is a minor, estate, an incompetent person, or person laboring under disabilities, the guardian or other personal representative of such person shall be served and such guardian or personal representative resides outside the county or is a nonresident of this state, he shall be served as provided for in subsection (c) of this article. If such owner or party in interest has no guardian or personal representative, service shall be perfected by serving the judge of the probate court of the county at least 30 days prior to the date of the hearing which judge shall stand in the place of and protect the rights of such minor, estate, or incompetent person or appoint a guardian ad litem for such person. (e) In the event of unknown persons or unborn remaindermen who are likely to have any rights in the property or interest or the proceeds thereof, the judge of the probate court of Atkinson County shall be personally served at least 30 days prior to the date of the hearing, and it shall be the duty of the judge of the probate court to stand in the place of and protect the rights of such unknown parties or unborn remaindermen. (f) In the event the whereabouts of any owner or party in interest is unknown and the same cannot be ascertained by the public officer in the exercise of reasonable diligence or if any owner or party in interest cannot, after due diligence, be served as provided in this article, the public officer shall make an affidavit to that effect and serve by publication in the manner provided in this article, and such publication shall be sufficient proof that service was perfected. (g) A notice of lis pendens shall be filed in the office of the clerk of superior court of Atkinson County at the time of filing the complaint in the appropriate court. Such notice shall have the same force and effect as other lis pendens notices provided by law. (h) Orders and other filings made subsequent to service of the initial complaint shall be served in the manner provided in this article on the owner and any party in interest who answers the complaint or appears at the hearing. Any party who fails to answer or appear at the hearing shall be deemed to have waived all further notice in the proceedings. Sec. 38-29. - Abatement of nuisances—Petition; notice to appear. Any person annoyed by any nuisance may apply to the city by written petition, in which that person shall describe the thing complained of as a nuisance, where it is located, and the name of the person maintaining the nuisance and pray that the nuisance be abated. The petition shall be filed with the court clerk, who shall thereupon issue a rule nisi addressed to the defendant, requiring that person to be and appear before the city municipal court at a named time and place and show cause why the alleged nuisance should be abated. A copy of the petition and rule nisi shall be served on the defendant personally, or by leaving it with a person who is competent at the defendant's residence, by the chief of police or any police officer or any legal officer of the city, who shall make an entry on the original petition showing the time and method of service; provided, the clerk may, without a petition, issue such rule nisi, which shall describe the thing complained of as a nuisance, where located, and be addressed to the person maintaining the thing complained of, which shall be served as provided in this section. (Code 1975, § 5-402-A; Ord. of 10-1-1991, § 5-402-A) Sec. 38-30. - Same—Hearing. When such petition is served as provided in this article, the judge of the municipal court shall hear, at the time and place appointed, evidence regarding the alleged nuisance. All such hearings shall be conducted in accordance with the rules of the municipal court. (Code 1975, § 5-402-A; Ord. of 10-1-1991, § 5-402-A) Sec. 38-31. - Same—By owner upon order. If the judge of the municipal court of the city adjudges an object or thing a nuisance, and orders its removal, it shall be the duty of the person erecting, causing or maintaining the nuisance to remove or abate the nuisance within the time period prescribed by the judge. A failure or refusal of the defendant to comply with the judge's order shall be punishable as a contempt of court. (Code 1975, § 5-402-A; Ord. of 10-1-1991, § 5-402-A) Sec. 38-32. - Same—Performance by city; collection of cost. If the defendant fails or refuses to remove or abate the nuisance as directed by the judge of the municipal court, the chief administrative officer or his designated representative shall forthwith abate the nuisance and report the abatement to the clerk, together with a bill of costs incurred. The clerk shall thereupon issue an execution for the expenses and costs incurred against the defendant, and the chief of police shall proceed to collect the execution by levy and sale as in the case of a tax fi. fa. (Code 1975, § 5-402-A; Ord. of 10-1-1991, § 5-402-A) Secs. 38-33—38-52. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - GRASS AND WEEDS
Sec. 38-53. - Notice to remove, responsibility of owners. All persons, firms, corporations and associations, owning or in the possession of, or exercising control over, any lot or parcel of land within the city are hereby required to mow or remove therefrom all weeds, grass and underbrush over twelve inches in height within ten days from the receipt of an order from the city clerk ordering such mowing or removal of such weeds, grass and underbrush. (Code 1975, § 5-401) Sec. 38-54. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Weeds shall be held to include all rank vegetable growth which exhale unpleasant and noxious odors, and also high and rank vegetable growth that may conceal filthy deposits. (Code 1975, § 5-402) Sec. 38-55. - Failure to remove. Upon failure to remove or mow to a height not exceeding 12 inches, such weeds, grass or underbrush within ten days from the receipt of such order from the city clerk, the city shall have the weeds, grass or underbrush removed at the expense of the owner or persons exercising control over such parcel of land. The mayor and council shall establish a minimum charge to the owner or possessor of the land for the city to remove such weeds, grass and underbrush. (Code 1975, § 5-403) Secs. 38-56—38-83. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - LITTER
Sec. 38-84. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Litter means all sand, gravel, slag, brickbats, rubbish, waste material, tin cans, refuse, garbage, trash, debris, dead animals, or discarded materials of every kind and description. (Code 1975, § 5-501) Sec. 38-85. - Placement of litter in receptacles so as to prevent scattering. Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. (Code 1975, § 5-502) Sec. 38-86. - Sweeping litter into gutters prohibited. No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the city the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk in front of their premises free of litter. (Code 1975, § 5-503) Sec. 38-87. - Merchants' duty to keep sidewalks free of litter and merchandise. No person owning or occupying a place of business shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the city the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. Persons owning or occupying places of business within the city shall keep the sidewalk in front of their business premises free of litter, merchandise and any other obstructions preventing the free movement of pedestrians. (Code 1975, § 5-504)

div.head: Chapter 42 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Limitation on home rule powers of municipal corporations with respect to duplication of state criminal offenses, Ga. Const. art. III, § VI, ¶ IV, and O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2); Criminal Code of Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 16-1-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 42-1—42-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PERSONS AND PROPERTY
Sec. 42-19. - Penalties. Any person who shall commit any act or offense declared unlawful, prohibited by, or punishable under, or by virtue of, any provisions in this chapter within said city, or its police jurisdiction as defined in Charter section 6.03, shall, unless otherwise provided, on conviction of each such offense in the municipal court of said city, be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-9 of of this Code. (Code 1947, § 79; Code 1975, § 6-101) Sec. 42-20. - Injuring trees and public property. It shall be unlawful for any person to cut down or injure in any way any trees on the sidewalks or on the public streets, or to injure or deface any property of this city. (Code 1947, § 82; Code 1975, § 6-102) State Law reference— Unlawful to damage, injure or interfere with property of public utility company, municipalities or political subdivisions, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25. Sec. 42-21. - Intoxication and disorderly conduct. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to be and appear in an intoxicated condition on the streets, on the steps of any building, in alleys, bus stations, railroad stations, filling stations, stores, any public place, or within the curtilage of any private residence not his own other than by invitation of the owner or lawful occupant, which condition is made manifest by boisterousness, by indecent condition or act, or by vulgar, profane, loud, or unbecoming language. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person, whether intoxicated or not, to become so boisterous or disorderly as to: (1) Act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another person whereby such person is placed in reasonable fear of the safety of such person's life, limb, or health; (2) Act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another person whereby the property of such person is placed in danger of being damaged or destroyed; (3) Without provocation, use to or of another person in such other person's presence opprobrious or abusive words which by their very utterance tend to incite to an immediate breach of the peace, that is to say, words which as a matter of common knowledge and under ordinary circumstances will, when used to or of another person in such other person's presence, naturally tend to provoke violent resentment, that is, words commonly called fighting words; or (4) Without provocation, use obscene and vulgar or profane language in the presence of or by telephone to a person under the age of 14 years which threatens an immediate breach of the peace. (Code 1947, § 84; Code 1975, § 6-103) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. §§ 16-11-39, 16-11-41. Sec. 42-22. - Posting bills. It shall be unlawful for any person to post, or cause to be posted, any bill on any building within the corporate limits of this city without the consent of the owner of the same. (Code 1947, § 111; Code 1975, § 6-107) Sec. 42-23. - Emergency telephones. (a) No person shall use a police telephone for personal calls or for any other use except police purposes. (b) No person shall use a fire department telephone for any purpose except to report a fire or for other fire department purposes. (c) No person shall ring a police or fire department telephone except for police or fire department purposes. (Code 1975, § 6-109; Ord. of 3-10-1953) Sec. 42-24. - Air rifles. No person shall shoot an air rifle or BB gun in the city limits. Any person violating this section shall pay all property damage caused by such act in addition to any other penalty imposed by the court. (Code 1975, § 6-110; Ord. of 8-10-1965) Sec. 42-25. - Loitering or prowling. (a) No person shall be in a place at a time and/or in a manner not usual for law-abiding individuals under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety or persons or property in the vicinity. (b) Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether alarm is warranted is the fact that the person takes flight upon the appearance of a law enforcement officer, refuses to identify himself, or manifestly endeavors to conceal himself or any object. Unless flight by the person or other circumstances make it impracticable, a law enforcement officer shall, prior to any arrest for an offense under this section, afford the person an opportunity to dispel any alarm or immediate concern which would otherwise be warranted by requesting the person to identify himself and explain his presence and conduct. No person shall be convicted of an offense under this section if the law enforcement officer failed to comply with the foregoing procedure or if it appears at trial that the explanation given by the person was true and would have dispelled the alarm or immediate concern. (Code 1975, § 6-111A; Ord. of 8-13-1991) Sec. 42-26. - Drinking alcoholic beverages on public property. No person shall tipple, or drink any spirituous, malt, or fermented liquors, on any public square, street, alley, sidewalk, park or cemetery within the city. (Code 1963, § 2509; Code 1975, § 6-112; Res. of 4-11-1978) Sec. 42-27. - Shoplifting. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to commit theft by taking when in any mercantile establishment within the city in which merchandise valued at $300.00 or less is displayed for sale in such manner as to be readily accessible to persons shopping therein, as follows: (1) Conceal or take possession of any such merchandise; (2) Alter the price tag or other price marking on such merchandise; (3) Interchange the label or price tag from one item of merchandise with a label or price tag from another item of merchandise; (4) Transfer any such merchandise from a container in which it may be displayed to any other container; or (5) Wrongfully causes the amount paid to be less than the merchant's stated price for the merchandise, with the intent to appropriate such merchandise to his own use, or to deprive the owner of possession thereof, or of the value thereof, in whole or part. (b) The crime of theft by taking under the circumstances of this section shall also be known as shoplifting. (Code 1975, § 6-113) State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 16-8-14. Sec. 42-28. - Hurling missiles. It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or shoot in or upon any public square, street, alley, park or sidewalk, or into the lot of any citizen, by hand or with a sling, or from any "flip" or other projectile instrument, operating by the elasticity of rubber or other material, any shot, bullet, stone or other missile of any kind whatever. (Code 1963, § 2504; Code 1975, § 6-121) Sec. 42-29. - Flying kites. No person shall fly a kite upon or over any of the streets or sidewalks of this city. (Code 1963, § 2505; Code 1975, § 6-122) Sec. 42-30. - Curfew for minors. (a) Hours; exceptions. It shall be unlawful for minors under the age of 18 years to assemble, congregate, or be upon the streets or sidewalks of the city unless accompanied by a parent or guardian of such minor, after 12:00 a.m. and before 6:00 a.m. This subsection shall not apply to such minors as may be sent to the business portion of the streets and sidewalks of the city by their parent or guardian with written authority from such parent or guardian for such occasion. (b) Procedure in case of violation. It shall be the duty of the police officers of the city, on finding any such minors that are prohibited from being on the streets, as aforesaid, to admonish such minor to go to his home; and should said minor fail and neglect to comply, the police officer shall arrest the offending minor, and after arresting said minor, immediately notify the parent or guardian of such minor, that unless such parent or guardian shall come and take such minor off the streets, the arresting officer shall then detain said minor until directions shall have been given by the mayor as to custody. (Code 1963, §§ 2538, 2539; Code 1975, §§ 6-123, 6-124) Sec. 42-31. - Causing congregations on streets. The mayor in his discretion, may grant special permits in writing, to worthy persons for the purpose of speaking, preaching the gospel, or to genuine members in good standing of the Salvation Army, or to vendors of medicine, merchandise or other such things for the sale thereof, or for public shows or exhibitions, within the city, when all other regulations of the city have been complied with, only upon the condition that such person shall engage in the same on some vacant lot, or in some hall, room, building, or other similar place, not upon said streets or sidewalks, and in that event, such persons shall not be permitted to go upon the streets or sidewalks for the purpose of taking collections or soliciting donations in money or other thing of value. (Code 1963, § 2409; Code 1975, § 6-125(c)) Sec. 42-32. - Damaging utilities and other property. It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully break, injure, deface, damage, destroy or improperly interfere with any fireplug, water main or fixture, any sewerage main or fixture, gas main or fixture, electric light or fixture, any telephone, electric light or telegraph pole, or wire: any pump, boiler, engine; any cistern, spring or aqueduct; any pump, lamp, tree or boxing around the same; any public clock, fire engine, truck or apparatus, or any other public property within the city. (Code 1963, § 2501; Code 1975, § 6-127) State Law reference— Unlawful to intentionally injure or destroy equipment or other apparatus of city used for public services, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25. Sec. 42-33. - Bathing in ponds or creeks. It shall be unlawful for any person, in the daytime, to bathe in any pond, or creek, in sight of any person who might be on a street, or on the bridges or causeways over the same. (Code 1963, § 2507; Code 1975, § 6-128) Sec. 42-34. - Loitering—Near schools; disrupting discipline of school. It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter at or near any public school house, or to engage by conversation, sign or otherwise, the attention of any of the pupils at said school to the disturbance of the same, or the detriment of the discipline of such schools. (Code 1963, § 2516; Code 1975, § 6-142) Sec. 42-35. - Same—Near churches; disturbing religious assembly. It shall be unlawful for persons to congregate in and around any church, either before, after, or during divine service, in such a disorderly or rude manner as to become and be offensive, and a disturbance to those attending such church; and it shall be unlawful for any persons, by such unseemly gatherings, or by loud talking, whistling, or laughing, or in any other manner to disturb any congregation of people assembled for divine service in this city. (Code 1963, § 2517; Code 1975, § 6-143) Secs. 42-36—42-58. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Giving massages in places used for lewdness, prostitution, assignation or masturbation for hire, O.C.G.A. § 16-6-17; governing authority has power to enact legislation to restrict operation of adult bookstores, explicit media outlets, and adult movie houses to areas zoned for commercial or industrial purposes, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-3; establishment, maintenance or use of building, structure or place for unlawful sexual purposes, O.C.G.A. § 41-3-1.
Sec. 42-59. - Findings. It is the finding of the council after reviewing relevant studies that public nudity (either partial or total) under circumstances related to nude bars or establishments offering so-called nude entertainment or adult entertainment, causes and begets criminal behavior and tends to create undesirable community conditions. Among the acts of criminal behavior found to be associated with public nudity are disorderly conduct, prostitution, public indecency and drug trafficking. Among the undesirable community conditions identified with the concentration of adult entertainment are depreciation of property values in neighborhoods surrounding nude bars or adult entertainment establishments where nude bars are located, increased expenditure for and allocation of law enforcement personnel to preserve law and order, increased burdens on the judicial system as a consequence of the criminal behavior hereinabove described, and acceleration of community blight by the concentration of adult entertainment establishments in particular areas. Other negative effects which are found by the council are the apparent connection of these establishments to organized crime and illegal drug sales, the potential spread of communicable diseases to law enforcement personnel who answer calls at adult establishments and to patrons of such establishments; and the potential proliferation of adult entertainment establishments after the initial siting of an adult entertainment establishment in a particular neighborhood. The council therefore finds that it is in the best interest of the health, welfare, safety and morals and preservation of its business, neighborhoods, and of schools, and parks to prevent the adverse impact of adult entertainment establishments. Therefore the council finds that the prohibition of live nude conduct in establishments is in the public welfare by furthering legitimate governmental interests, such as reducing criminal activity, protecting against property devaluation and deterioration, and eliminating undesirable community conditions normally associated with establishments and allow and/or encourage nudity, and that such prohibition will not infringe upon the protected constitutional rights of freedom of speech. To that end this article is hereby adopted. This article does not and is not intended to allow or license any business, establishment or activity which would otherwise be unlawful. (Code 1975, § 6-111C; Ord. of 9-10-1996, § 1(a)) Sec. 42-60. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Business establishment or establishment means a business within the incorporated areas of the city. License means a license issued by the governing body. Licensee means any person or entity to whom a license for a business establishment has been issued by the governing body, including the officers and agents of the licensee. Live means any activity which is carried on by actual living persons in the physical presence of patrons. Live entertainment means entertainment for the benefit of patrons which is carried on in the actual physical presence of such patrons including, but not limited to, dancing. Mainstream performance house means a theater, concert hall, auditorium or similar establishment which regularly features live performances such as plays or concerts which are not disguised or characterized by an emphasis on the depiction, description or display or the featuring of specific anatomical areas or specified sexual activities and where such depiction, if any, is only incidental to the primary purpose of any performance. Premises means the definite closed or partitioned establishment, whether room, shop or building, including the sidewalk serving area or outside, open air or patio type serving area on the private property of an establishment. Specified anatomical areas means any of the following: (1) Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals or pubic region; cleft of the buttocks; or any portion of the breast encompassed within an area falling below the horizontal line one would have to draw to intercept a point above the top of the areola, or any portion of the areola, or any simulation thereof. This definition shall include the entire lower portion of the human breast, but shall not include any portion of the cleavage of the human breast exhibited by a dress, blouse, shirt, leotard, bathing suit, or other wearing apparel, provided the areola is not so exposed. (2) Human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. Specified sexual activities means and includes any of the following: (1) The fondling or other erotic touching of human genitals, public region, buttocks, anus or breasts; (2) Sex acts, normal or perverted, actual or simulated, including intercourse, oral copulation, sodomy, anal intercourse, anal copulation, bestiality, direct physical stimulation of unclothed genitals, flagellation or torture in the context of a sexual relationship, anilingus, buggery, coprophagy, coprophilia, cunnilingus, fellatio, necrophilia, pederasty, pedophilia, piquerism, sapphism, or zooerasty; (3) Masturbation, actual or simulated; (4) The displaying of the male or female pubic hair, anus, vulva or genitals; (5) Masochism, erotic or sexually oriented torture, beating or the infliction of pain; (6) Erotic or lewd touching, fondling or other sexual contact with an animal by a human being; or (7) Excretory functions as part of or in connection with any of the activities set forth in subsections (1) through (4) of this definition. (Code 1975, § 6-111C; Ord. of 9-10-1996, § 1(b)) Sec. 42-61. - Conduct prohibited. The following types of entertainment, attire and conduct are prohibited upon any premises or within any business establishment including, but not limited to, establishments licensed to sell, serve or dispense alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises within the city. (1) The employment or use of any person live, in any capacity when such person is unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing, as to expose any portion of his specified anatomical areas. (2) Live entertainment where any person appears unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing as to expose any portion of his specified anatomical areas or where such person performs acts of specified sexual activities or acts which simulate specified sexual activity as defined herein. (3) The holding, promotion, sponsoring or allowance of any contest, promotion, special night, event or any other activity where live patrons of the licensed establishment are encouraged or allowed to engage in any of the conduct prescribed in subsections (1) and (2) of this section. (Code 1975, § 6-111C; Ord. of 9-10-1996, § 1(c)) Sec. 42-62. - Penalties. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to perform any acts prohibited hereby and any person so doing shall be guilty of an offense and shall upon conviction thereof in the city court be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-9 of this Code. (b) It shall be unlawful for a licensee to permit any conduct prohibited hereby which he knows or has reasonable cause to know is taking place on the premises. Any licensee so permitting shall be guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof in the city court, shall be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-9 of this Code. The license of any licensee shall upon his conviction of a violation of this article, be forthwith revoked. (c) All of the penalties stated in this section shall also be applicable to any person who is in control of or managing the establishment at the time any of the offenses stated herein occur. Said person must be shown to know or have reasonable cause to know that the offenses are taking place. (Code 1975, § 6-111C; Ord. of 9-10-1996, § 2)

div.head: Chapter 46 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Power to provide parks, recreation areas, programs and facilities, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(5); authority of municipality to construct and operate parks, swimming pools, golf courses, recreation grounds and buildings used for sports, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3; establishment of recreation systems authorized, O.C.G.A. § 36-64-1 et seq.
Sec. 46-1. - Establishment. The city adopts the establishment of a recreation department and the hiring of a full time recreation director. (Res. No. 430, 2-8-2005) Sec. 46-2. - Powers and duties of mayor and council. The mayor and council shall conduct and supervise public playgrounds, indoor recreation centers, and other recreational facilities owned or controlled by the city. They may conduct or sponsor any form of recreation or cultural activity that will employ the leisure of the people in a wholesome or constructive manner. They may conduct such activities on properties under their control, on public properties with the consent of the authorities thereof, and on private properties with consent of the owners. (Code 1975, § 4-201) Sec. 46-3. - Park property. No person in a park shall: (1) Willfully mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with, displace or remove any buildings, bridges, tables, benches, fireplaces, railings, paving or paving material, waterlines or other public utilities or parts or appurtenances thereof, signs, notices, or placards, whether temporary or permanent, monuments, stakes, posts or other boundary markers, or other structures or equipment, facilities or park property or appurtenance whatsoever either real or personal. (2) Fail to cooperate in maintaining restrooms and washrooms in a neat and sanitary condition. (3) Throw, discharge, or otherwise place or cause to be placed in the waters of any fountain, pond, lake, stream, bay or other body of water in or adjacent to any park or any tributary, stream, storm sewer, or drain flowing into such waters, any substance, matter or thing, liquid or solid, which will or may result in the pollution of said waters. (4) Have brought in or shall dump, deposit or leave any bottles, broken glass, ashes, paper, boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, waste, garbage, or refuse, or other trash. No such refuse or trash shall be placed in any waters in or contiguous to any park, or left anywhere on the grounds thereof, but shall be placed in the proper receptacles where these are provided; where receptacles are not so provided, all such rubbish or waste shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence, and properly disposed of elsewhere. (Code 1975, § 4-202; Mo. of 7-13-1982) State Law reference— Unlawful to damage, injure or interfere with property of municipalities or political subdivisions, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25; unlawful to dump or leave or to cause or permit the dumping or leaving of litter on any public or private property in this state or any waters in this state, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-43. Sec. 46-4. - Operating policy. (a) Every park that is the property of the city shall be opened daily to the public. Any section, or part of the park may be declared closed to the public by the mayor and council at any time and for any interval of time, either temporarily or at regular or stated intervals. (b) Whenever any association or organization desires to use park facilities for a particular purpose, such as picnics, parties or theatrical or entertainment performances, a representative of the association or organization shall first obtain a permit from the mayor and council for such purposes. The city clerk may adopt an application form to be used for such situations. (c) The mayor and council shall grant the application if it appears that the association or organization will not interfere with the general use of the park by the individual members of the public and if the association or organization meets all other conditions contained in this chapter. The application may contain a requirement for an indemnity bond to protect the city from any liability of any kind or character and to protect city property from damage, and shall contain such a provision if a swimming pool is to be utilized by the association or organization. (d) The mayor and council may deny an application based on: (1) Prior unmanageable, unruly, unlawful, detrimental or damaging conduct or actions of the person, group, association, organization or entity making the request with regard to use of a public park or recreational facility; or (2) When it appears that the city does not have the budgetary capacity or manpower resources available to provide garbage pick-up, law enforcement support, or public works employees support to handle the necessary maintenance and protection of the city's public parks or recreational facilities. (Code 1975, § 4-203(a)—(c)) Sec. 46-5. - Use of public parks, fields, and facilities. (a) At the discretion of the mayor and council, any person or organization desiring to use public parks, fields, and facilities may be charged a fee for such use. (b) Any person or organization that uses a public park, field, or facility will be responsible for removing any trash, litter, or debris attributable to his or its activities at the public park, field, or facility. (c) Any person or organization that uses a public park, field, or facility will be responsible for any damage to the public park, field, or facility that is attributable to his or its activities at said location. (Mo. of 7-13-1982) Sec. 46-6. - Prohibited activities. No person in a park shall: (1) Picnic or lunch in a place other than those designated for that purpose. Attendants shall have the authority to regulate the activities in such areas when necessary to prevent congestion and to secure the maximum use for the comfort and convenience of all. Visitors shall comply with any directions given to achieve this end. (2) Use any portion of the picnic areas or of any of the buildings or structures therein for the purpose of holding picnics to the exclusion of other persons, nor shall any person use such area and facilities for an unreasonable time if the facilities are crowded. (3) Leave a picnic area before the fire is completely extinguished and before all trash in the nature of boxes, papers, cans, bottles, garbage and other refuse is placed in the disposal receptacles where provided. If no such trash receptacles are available, then refuse and trash shall be carried away from the park area by the picnicker to be properly disposed of elsewhere. (Code 1975, § 4-203(d)) Sec. 46-7. - Dressing on beach, etc. No person in a park shall dress or undress on any beach, or in any vehicle, toilet or other place, except in such bathing houses or structures as may be provided for that purpose. (Code 1975, § 4-204) Sec. 46-8. - Speed of vehicles. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle in any area in a park in excess of 15 miles per hour. (Code 1975, § 4-205) Sec. 46-9. - Merchandising, advertising and signs. No person in a park except a concessionaire licensed by the city shall: (1) Expose or offer for sale any article or thing, nor shall he station or place any stand, cart, or vehicle for the transportation, sale or display of any such article or thing. (2) Announce, advertise, or call the public attention in any way to any article or service for sale or hire. (3) Paste, glue, tack or otherwise post any sign, placard, advertisement, or inscription whatever, nor shall any person erect or cause to be erected any sign whatever on any public lands or highways or roads adjacent to a park. (Code 1975, § 4-206)

div.head: Chapter 50 - SOLID WASTE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authorization to provide garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(2); Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.
Sec. 50-1. - Container required. The owner, agent, and occupant of any premises, improved or unimproved, in the city whereon garbage is created, shall provide a rust-resisting watertight container or containers having a tightfitting cover; such container or containers shall be of sufficient size as to be easily handled, and of such number as to receive the garbage accumulation between periods of collection from such premises, and shall be placed in a location which is easily accessible for the purpose of having their contents removed, all residents and business establishments that do not have a garbage container shall be liable to a fine ten days after notification. The fine shall be set by resolution of the mayor and council from time to time, and available for public examination in the fee and rate schedule in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1975, § 4-401) Sec. 50-2. - General regulations. (a) It shall be unlawful for such owner, agent, or occupant of any such premises to have, maintain, or keep any garbage on any premises except in such garbage containers as are provided for in section 50-1. (b) Containers shall be tightly covered at all times except when momentarily opened to receive garbage or to have the contents removed. (c) The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all public and private premises, as well as all places of business, hotels, restaurants, and all other premises, whether used for business or residential purposes. (d) For the purpose of enforcing this chapter, any person living on any premises and the person in charge of any business shall be deemed an occupant; and any person receiving the rent, in whole or in part, of any premises, shall be deemed an agent. (Code 1975, § 4-402) Sec. 50-3. - Fee. All residents within the city limits shall be charged monthly for garbage pickup, as well as all business establishments within the city limits . The amount of the fee shall be set by resolution of the mayor and council from time to time, and available for public examination in the fee and rate schedule in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1975, § 4-403) Sec. 50-4. - County regulations adopted; supplementary provisions. (a) The city hereby adopts all the provisions included in the county solid waste resolution. (b) The following subsections are adopted by the city council to supplement the county resolution within the city: (1) The city shall service each residential, industrial and commercial receptacle inside the city limits once per week. (2) Containers placed by residents, industrial and commercial establishments for service by the city must be standard metal or plastic containers covered by a suitable lid. (3) It shall be unlawful to dispose of garbage or refuse on any land in a manner that would create a nuisance. (4) It shall be unlawful to throw or deposit garbage or refuse on or to litter city streets and public property. (5) Large bulky items, which do not appropriately fit into a receptacle such as shrubbery trimmings or large tree limbs, or similar items shall be placed at the curb-side by the customer for pickup by the city. (Code 1975, § 4-405)

div.head: Chapter 54 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— City has power to construct and maintain roads, including curbs, sidewalks, street lights and devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4); municipal street systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-90 et seq.; powers with respect to municipal street system, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-92; regulation of maintenance and use of public roads generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 54-1. - Grade lines. The city engineer, or chief of police, when there is no engineer elected by the mayor and council, shall establish a grade line from such point as the mayor and council may decide upon, and, from time to time, such street lines as persons and corporations contemplating the erection of buildings and structures may demand; in conformity to which grade and street lines all buildings and structures of any character whatsoever in the city must be erected, whenever the same are to be erected abutting any sidewalk, or within five feet of any sidewalk in said city. (1) It shall be unlawful to erect any building or other structure, coming within the above provision, and said city without first presenting the plans and specification of said buildings or structures to the mayor and council for their approval and instructions as to the proper line and elevation of said buildings or structures. (2) All persons violating this section by failing to submit said plans and specifications for the approval and direction of the mayor and council, or having submitted the same, shall fail to conform to the instructions of the said mayor and council, shall be punished as provided in section 6.03 of the city Charter. (Code 1947, § 122; Code 1975, § 5-701) Sec. 54-2. - Excavations; obstructions. All parties making or causing to be made any excavations, or by placing or causing to be placed any obstruction of any character of such nature as to endanger the safety of persons or property in any street, alley, unenclosed lot or public place within said city, are hereby required to place and keep a sufficient number of red-danger-signal lights, not exceeding 50 feet apart, where more than one light is required, to put the public on full notice of such place or thing of danger. All persons who place obstructions upon the streets or sidewalks of the city shall remove same from the sidewalk at their expense as soon as practicable after completion of building. If they fail to remove said obstruction when so notified by the chief of police, they shall be guilty of a city misdemeanor and shall be fined according to the limits and terms of section 6.03 of the city Charter. Anyone tearing up the sidewalk or paved street for the purpose of laying pipe or placing underground wire shall be required to replace said sidewalk and paved streets by new paving in as good a condition as it was before tearing it up. And upon the failure to do so, after the notice of the chief of police to make the repairs they shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and be punished according to section 6.03 of the city Charter. (Code 1947, § 123; Code 1975, § 5-702) Sec. 54-3. - Utility pole permits. All the electric light companies, telephone companies, telegraph and railroad companies and all other parties before placing any poles upon the streets of the city shall file an application with the city clerk in which they shall state the number of poles they desire to place on the street and on what street they desire to place same; which application shall be referred to the street committee for its approval, and upon the failure of any person or company to make this application to the city clerk before the installation of any poles they shall be guilty of a city misdemeanor and shall be punished according to section 6.03 of the city Charter. (Code 1947, § 124; Code 1975, § 5-703) Sec. 54-4. - Curfew authorized. The mayor is hereby authorized and empowered to decree or order a curfew in the city at any time he may consider it necessary or needed in said city to provide protection for persons and/or property in said city, and to provide for the good order, good morals, peace and tranquility within the corporate limits of the city, and he is further authorized and empowered to order said curfew to remain in effect for and during the hours or days that he may consider said curfew to be necessary or needed, and he may end said curfew at such time as he considers it to be no longer necessary or needed. (Code 1975, § 5-705; Ord. of 8-11-1970, § 1) Secs. 54-5—54-28. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PARADE PERMITS
Sec. 54-29. - Permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person, or group of persons, or any convention, association or organization of any kind to parade, march or demonstrate upon, through, in or about the streets, sidewalks or other public places in the city without first obtaining a permit in writing from the mayor of said city, and said mayor is hereby authorized and empowered to promulgate, formulate and set up the rules and regulations governing each parade, march or demonstration within the corporate limits of the city, and he has full supervision over such activities. (Code 1975, § 5-706; Ord. of 8-11-1970, § 2) Sec. 54-30. - Exceptions. This article shall not apply to: (1) Funeral processions; (2) Students going to and from school classes or participating in educational activities providing such conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of proper school authorities; (3) A government agency acting within the scope of its functions; (4) Any sporting event. Sec. 54-31. - Application. (a) Time limit for filing. A person seeking issuance of a parade permit shall file an application with the mayor on forms provided by the office of the city clerk not less than ten days nor more than 30 days before the date on which it proposes to conduct the parade. (b) Contents. The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: (1) The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade. (2) If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by any organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization. (3) The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade chairman chairperson and who will be responsible for its conduct. (4) The date when the parade is to be conducted. (5) The route to be travelled, if any, the starting point and termination point. (6) The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which, will constitute such parade; the type of animals and description of vehicles. (7) The hours when such parade will start and terminate. (8) A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the widths of the streets, if any, proposed to be transversed. (9) If such parade is to be held in a city park, a statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the city park, or other public area on which the parade is proposed to take place. (10) The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade. (11) The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at such assembly area or areas. (12) The interval of space to be maintained between units of such parade. (13) If the parade is designed to be held by, on behalf of, or for any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file with the police department a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade, authorizing the applicant to apply for the parade on his behalf. (14) Information regarding any public address or loudspeaker system to be used during such parade, including the approximate number of decibels to be emitted from such system. (c) Fee. A fee shall be remitted to the office of the city clerk at the time of filing the application for a parade permit. The amount of the fee shall be set by resolution of the mayor and council from time to time, and available for public examination in the schedule of fees and rates in the office of the city clerk. Sec. 54-32. - Late applications. Late applications for a parade permit will not be considered. Sec. 54-33. - Standards for issuance. The mayor shall issue a parade permit when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, it is found: (1) The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route or place of occurrence. (2) The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement or the place of occurrence and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city. (3) The conduct of such parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances and other emergency vehicles as to prevent normal ambulance and other emergency service to portions of the city other than that to be occupied by the proposed parade and areas contiguous thereto. (4) The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with police, fire and other emergency services to areas contiguous to such assembly areas. (5) The conduct of such parade will not interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment en route to a fire. (6) The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or to create a disturbance. (7) The parade is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any product, goods or event, and is designed to be held purely for private profit. (8) The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route. Sec. 54-34. - Notice of rejection. The mayor shall act upon the application for a parade permit within three business days after the filing thereof. If the mayor disapproves the application based on the standards listed in this article, he shall mail to the applicant, within three business days after the date which the application was filed, a notice of his action stating the reasons for his denial of the permit. Notice shall be deemed complete when mailed. Sec. 54-35. - Appeal procedure. Any person aggrieved shall have the right to appeal the denial of a parade permit to the city council. The appeal shall be taken within 60 days after notice. The city council shall act upon the appeal within 30 days after its receipts. Sec. 54-36. - Alternative permits. The mayor, in denying an application for a parade permit, shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the parade on a date, at a time, or over a route, or in a place, different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within five days after notice of the action of the mayor, file a written notice of acceptance with the mayor. An alternate parade permit shall conform to the requirements of and shall have the effect of a parade permit under this article. Sec. 54-37. - Notice to the city and other officials. Immediately upon the issuance of a parade permit, the mayor shall send a copy thereof to the following: (1) Each member of the city council. (2) The city attorney. (3) The city clerk. (4) The chief of police. Sec. 54-38. - Contents of permit. Each parade permit shall state the following information: (1) Starting time. (2) The portions of the streets, if any, to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade. (3) The portions of any parks or public property to be occupied by the parade. (4) The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof. (5) Such other information as the mayor, city council, city attorney, and chief of police shall find necessary to the enforcement of this article. Sec. 54-39. - Duties of the permittee. A permittee under this article shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. (1) The parade chairperson or other person heading or leading such activity shall carry the parade permit on his person during the conduct of the parade. (2) The parade chairperson or other person heading or leading such activity shall be solely responsible for the cleanup of any papers, bottles, cans, animal excretions, or any other refuse left by participants in the parade. a. The parade chairperson or other person heading or leading such activity shall have a reasonable amount of time, but not to exceed 48 hours, to carry out such cleanup after any such activity. b. If such cleanup is not completed by the parade chairperson or other person heading or leading such activity within a reasonable amount of time, but not to exceed 48 hours, the city may commence cleanup and hold the parade chairperson or other person heading or leading such activity financially liable for any and all costs directly incurred by the city in such cleanup activity. c. In no instance shall the parade chairperson or other person heading or leading such activity be responsible for cleanup of the refuse left by spectators or other nonparticipant in the parade. Sec. 54-40. - Revocation of permit. The mayor or city council shall have the authority to revoke a parade permit issued under this article upon violation of any of the standards for issuance applied in this article. Sec. 54-41. - Violations; penalty. A violation of any part of this article shall be punishable under section 6.03 of the Charter of the city. (Code 1975, § 5-707; Ord. of 8-11-1970, § 3) Sec. 54-42. - Utility apparatus; diversion of services. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person intentionally and without authority to destroy, damage or tamper with any meter pipe, line, post, lamp or other apparatus owned by the city or by any company engaged in the manufacture or sale of electricity, gas, water, telephone, cable television, or other public service. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person intentionally and without authority to prevent a meter from properly registering the quantity of such service supplies, or in any way to interfere with the proper action of the city, or of a company engaged in the manufacture or sale of electricity, gas, water, telephone, cable television, or other public service, or intentionally to divert any of the services of the city or such company, or otherwise intentionally and without authority to use or cause to be used, without the consent of the city or such company, any service manufactured, sold or distributed by the city or such company. (c) No person shall knowingly receive the benefit of acts of diversion of or tampering with electricity, gas, water, telephone, cable television or other public services without the proper charge. (d) Proof that any of the acts hereinbefore specified if this action was done on premises in possession of an accused, or that the accused received the benefit of any such act, shall be prima facie evidence that the accused committed such act or aided and abetted in the commission thereof. (Code 1975, § 5-708; Ord. of 7-8-1980) State Law reference— Unlawful to damage, injure or interfere with property of municipalities, utilities, or political subdivisions, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25. Secs. 54-43—54-71. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - NUMBERING SYSTEM
Sec. 54-72. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Property means any house, residence, dwelling, place of profit or nonprofit business, office, industry, government buildings, factory, facility, mobile home, modular home and manufactured home. (Ord. of 10-11-2005, § 1) Sec. 54-73. - Numbering system established. There is hereby established a uniform system for numbering buildings fronting on all streets, avenues and public ways in the city. All houses and other buildings shall be numbered in accordance with the provisions of this article. (Code 1975, § 5-1001; Ord. of 12-13-1983, § 9) Sec. 54-74. - Base lines and quadrants designated. (a) The base line for numbering properties along all streets running north and south shall hereinafter be referred to as the east-west base line and shall be constituted as follows: Albany Avenue (Highway 82) from the east city limits westward to the west city limits. (b) The base line for numbering properties along all streets running east and west shall be hereinafter referred to as the north-south base line and shall be constituted as follows: Main Street (Highway 221-441) from the north city limits extending southward to the south city limits. (c) Each building to the north of the east-west base line and facing a street running in a northerly direction shall carry a number and address indicating its location north of said base line. (d) Each building to the south of the east west base line and facing a street running in a southerly direction shall carry a number and address indicating its location south of said base. (e) Each building to the west of the north-south base line and facing a street running in a westerly direction shall carry a number and address indicating its location west of said base line. (f) Each building to the east of the north-south base line and facing a street running in a easterly direction shall carry a number and address indicating its location east of said base line. (g) All buildings on diagonal streets shall be numbered the same as buildings on northerly and southerly streets if the diagonal runs more north and south and the same rule shall apply on easterly and westerly streets if the diagonal runs more east-west. (Code 1975, § 5-1002) Sec. 54-75. - Odd-even sides; separate numbers per entrance. (a) All buildings on the south and east sides of streets shall carry even numbers and all buildings on the north and west sides of streets shall carry odd numbers. (b) Where any one building has more than one entrance serving separate occupants a separate number shall be assigned to each entrance serving a separate occupant. If the building is not located on a lot, parcel or tract which would permit the assignment of one number to such entrance, letters (A,B,C,D and so on) shall be used. (Code 1975, § 5-1003) Sec. 54-76. - Central business district; other areas in the city. (a) All existing buildings in the central business district of the city shall be numbered. Business development expanding the central business district shall be numbered using the same process as for the original central business district. (b) In all other sections of the city numbers shall be assigned every 50 feet. (Code 1975, § 5-1004) Sec. 54-77. - Number on streets not extending to base line. All buildings facing streets not extending through the base lines shall be assigned the same relative numbers as if the streets had extended to the base line. (Code 1975, § 5-1005) Sec. 54-78. - Display of assigned numbers. (a) The assigned numbers shall be displayed at all times. (b) The numbers shall be conspicuously placed immediately above, on or at the side of the main entrance so that the number can be plainly seen from the street line. (c) Whenever any building is situated such that the main entrance is more than 50 feet from the street line or said entrance is obscured, then the numbers may be placed upon a gatepost, fence, or other post so that they may be easily seen from the street. (d) The numerals shall be no less than three inches in height and be made out of a durable and highly visible material. (Code 1975, § 5-1006) Sec. 54-79. - Use of letters of the alphabet. Where only one number can be assigned to a building the owner or agent of such building who desires distinctive numbers for different parts of said building shall use the suffix A, B, C, etc., as may be required. (Code 1975, § 5-1007) Sec. 54-80. - New buildings. Whenever any house, building or structure shall hereafter be erected or located in the city, in order to preserve the uniformity and continuity of the numbers of the houses and buildings, it shall be the duty of the owner to procure the correct numbers as designated by the city clerk for the property and to immediately fasten said numbers upon said building. (Code 1975, § 5-1008) Sec. 54-81. - 911 address numbering plan. (a) The purpose of this article is to enhance rapid location of properties by law enforcement, fire, rescue and emergency medical service personnel in the city. (b) It shall be the responsibility of the mayor of the city or his designee, to administer the general plan for numbering property located in the incorporated limits of the city. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, said mayor, or his designee, shall also assign a number to each property within the incorporated limits of the city. (Ord. of 10-11-2005, § 2) Sec. 54-82. - Standards for the proper display of addresses. (a) The owner and occupant of all property located in the incorporated limits of the city shall conspicuously display the number assigned to said property. (b) The owner and occupant of any property to which a number has been assigned shall affix the number in a conspicuous place as set forth in this article. (c) It shall be the duty of such owner and occupant of the property upon affixing the new number to remove any different number that might be mistaken for or confused with the number assigned. (d) All property shall have the correct address posted on the main structure of the property, or at the entrance to the property as provided for in subsection (e) of this section, where it will be clearly visible to persons or vehicles approaching the property. (e) When a property is more than 35 feet from the road, or when the view of same is blocked by trees, shrubs or other material, the numbers shall be on a tree, mailbox, fence, gate or lawn stake at the entrance to the property on the same side of the road as the entrance to the property and clearly visible and legible from the road. (f) All addresses shall be legible and shall be large enough to be seen easily from the road. Each number must be a minimum of three inches square. (g) Numbers shall be of contrasting color to their background for easy visibility. (h) Numbers shall be of reflective material and must be easily visible at night. (i) On corner lots, numbers shall be displayed on the frontage to which the property is facing. (j) In cases where more than one property has a single access, the principal address shall be displayed at the access and the sub address displayed on the property to which it applies. This is applicable to apartments, condominiums, mobile and manufactured home parks as well. (Ord. of 10-11-2005, § 3) Sec. 54-83. - Enforcement and penalties for violation. (a) Whenever the owner and occupant of an officially addressed property shall neglect or refuse to affix or inscribe the proper numbers as required by this article, the mayor or his designee shall serve notice on the owner and occupant at the address of a violation of this article. The owner and occupant shall affix the assigned number to the property in accordance with this article within ten days of the service of notice. If the owner and occupant shall fail to affix the number within said ten-day period such owner or occupant may be fined and imprisoned as set forth in this section and the numbers caused to be affixed by the mayor or his designee. (b) If the owner and occupant or person of any property to which a number has been assigned refuses to comply with the terms of this article or if any person shall take down, alter, injure or deface any number affixed or inscribed, such person shall be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-9 of this Code. Each day any violation of this article shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. (c) The city court shall have jurisdiction over violations of this section and all procedures for enforcement hereof shall be as provided in O.C.G.A. Article 4, Chapter 10, Title 15 (O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60 et seq.). Complaints of violations of any provision contained herein shall be brought before the city municipal court on a citation issued by the mayor, or his designee, and shall be prosecuted through the court. Violations of this section will be tried upon citations either with or without a prosecuting attorney as determined by the mayor. Service of citation shall be performed by the police of the city. Citations shall meet all the official requirements as specified in O.C.G.A. § 15-10-63. (Ord. of 10-11-2005, § 4)

div.head: Chapter 58 - TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Taxation power of municipal and county governments, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV, ¶ I(a) and (b)(2); ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq.; municipal power of ad valorem taxation to provide for financial assistance to its development authority, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-350 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - In General
Secs. 58-1—58-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - AD VALOREM TAXES
Sec. 58-19. - Levy of executions. Whenever an execution, issued in accordance with this article for unpaid taxes, is placed in his hands, the chief of police forthwith shall levy the same on the property pointed out in said execution, or a sufficiency thereof to satisfy the execution and cost. He shall then proceed to advertise and sell the property levied on, according to the provisions of the law governing sheriff's sales of similar property for state and county taxes. (Code 1947, § 53; Code 1975, § 3-301) Sec. 58-20. - Notice of levy. In all cases of levy upon real estate, or shares in a corporation, written notices of said levy shall be given to the owner thereof, if known, within five days after said levy, if the owner is in the city; if not in the city, notice shall be delivered by certified mail to him within said time, or in case of realty, said notice may be served on the tenant in possession. (Code 1947, § 54; Code 1975, § 3-302) State Law reference— Similar provision, O.C.G.A. § 9-13-13. Sec. 58-21. - City bidding at tax sale. The city clerk shall act for the city in bidding the amount of taxes and cost of property sold for taxes by the chief of police where no one bids that amount, and shall see that the chief of police makes the city a deed pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-359. (Code 1947, § 56; Code 1975, § 3-303) Sec. 58-22. - Records. It shall be the duty of the city clerk to prepare and keep in his office a book or record of all property purchased by the city at the tax sales, showing whose property was so purchased by the city at the tax sale, the amount bid by the clerk and what portion of the same was taxes and what portion was the clerk's and chief's cost, respectively. He shall also file and carefully keep in his office the deed made by the chief to the city, and the execution attached, which shall be delivered to him by the chief, also a copy of the newspaper in which any chief of police's sale, at which the city purchased, was advertised. (Code 1947, § 57; Code 1975, § 3-304) Sec. 58-23. - Redemption of property by owner. The owner desiring to redeem property so purchased by the city may do so in two years from the date of sale, by applying to the clerk of council, and upon compliance of any such person with the law may be allowed to do so; and the clerk shall be required to keep an account of all such money received from such sources. (Code 1947, § 58; Code 1975, § 3-305) Sec. 58-24. - Estimate of income and expenses; levy and calculation of tax. (a) The council as soon as practicable after receiving the tax returns from the county shall cause to be made up and entered on its minutes an accurate estimate of all sums which are or may be lawfully chargeable on the city and which ought to be paid within one year, and shall cause to be made up and so entered, a statement of the amount of taxable property and the income of the city from specific taxes and other sources, with the amount of funds on hand, if any. (b) The council shall then, by resolution or ordinance, order a levy of such tax as may, in the opinion of the council, be necessary with other sources of income to raise a sufficient amount to pay all charges against the city shown by the foregoing estimate which resolution or ordinance shall be placed on the minutes. The estimate and statement above provided for a resolution or ordinance levying the tax shall be published in the paper doing the city printing. (c) The clerk shall then calculate the amount of tax due from each taxpayer and open his books for collection of taxes. (Code 1947, §§ 60—62; Code 1975, §§ 3-306—3-308) Sec. 58-25. - Failure to pay tax. Whenever any person, firm or corporation shall fail or refuse to pay any taxes imposed under this article, within the time allowed for payment of the same, the clerk shall issue execution for the amount, duly signed by himself, and bearing test in the name of the mayor, directed to the chief of police or a police officer, commanding them of the lands and tenements, goods and chattels of the party in default, to make the amount due and cost; but should the owner thereof be unknown, the clerk shall issue the execution, against the property, describing the same in the execution and in any case execution may issue against the property directly for taxes due and unpaid on that particular property. (Code 1947, § 63; Code 1975, § 3-309) Secs. 58-26—58-53. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - INSURANCE COMPANIES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Local tax on life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1; local tax on other than life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2.
Sec. 58-54. - Company license. There is hereby levied an annual license fee upon each insurer doing business within the city in an amount set by resolution of the mayor and council from time to time, and available for public examination in the fee and rate schedule in the office of the city clerk. For each separate business location in excess of one not covered by this article, which is operating on behalf of such insurers within the city, there is hereby levied a license fee in an amount set by resolution of the mayor and council from time to time, and available for public examination in the fee and rate schedule in the office of the city clerk. For the purposes of this article, the term "insurer" means a company which is authorized to transact business in any of the classes of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5. (Code 1975, § 3-310; Ord. of 12-13-1994, § 1) Sec. 58-55. - License fees for insurers insuring certain risks at additional business locations.
